item.title: Hello world!
item.dc:creator: Bill
item.content:encoded: Welcome to WordPress. This is your first post. Edit or delete it, then start writing!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi, this is a comment. To get started with moderating, editing, and deleting comments, please visit the Comments screen in the dashboard. Commenter avatars come from Gravatar.

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: Bill
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Thought Process Behind Choosing A Tattoo
item.dc:creator: Bill
item.content:encoded: It's fine getting a tattoo because it means a lot to you, but I feel there is so much to be said for tattoos that are a piece of art.

item.title: Welcome to my Blog and Portfolio
item.dc:creator: Bill
item.content:encoded:
Heya everyone and welcome to my first Blog post.
My name is Bill Stapleton and I am currently a 3rd Year Creative Digital Media student studying in Blanchardstown. My main areas of interest in digital media are in Traditional and Digital Art and Design and Cinematography.
My interest in the industry started just before I started secondary school with Anime and Manga. The art style intrigued me and was the spark that would ignite my flame of desire to learn more and hone my skills. Up until this point in my life I had never been one of those people who were "good at art" and as far as I can recall was still of the impression that art was something you were born with. Not a skill that is practiced and gained. It was the low-key lust for the ability to create images, content, worlds of my own similar to those that I was watching that set me down the path of art, design and digital media. I started by watching Youtube videos online. I often find old pictures I drew from step by step guides from people like Mark Crilley and Lily Pichu with thanks written on them.
At this point I would also identify as someone who "enjoyed" photography but I was never really one to go out and take photos or take the craft seriously and learn the technicalities. I only ever occasionally used a point and shoot to take some photos and had some fun doing so. Oblivious to the intricacies and whole other side to photography that I was missing out on. My dad always took photos of us on family outings. And In a way ingrained in me his "Now tell me where are we today, and what are we doing..... What date is it?" methodology that I find myself drifting into whenever taking candid friendly video of close friends or family.
It was secondary school that I met, looking back now. Arguably one of my biggest inspirations in terms of my passion for art. My secondary school art teacher Clifton Rooney. He brought a whole new meaning to the subject for me and instilled a passion I still carry with me year later. I wholeheartedly feelsorry and sad for those who chose art as a subject, want to pursue it. And were met with for lack of a better term "Bad" art teachers. Too often do you find art teachers who ruin the subject for their students. Ask anyone. Mr Rooney was far from one of those teachers. He only ever did his best to give students the means to explore and exhaust any route they wanted. Giving them the skills, if they'd listen. To bring out the best in whatever it was they wanted to do. To the stage that he would stay behind on Wednesdays and let the leaving cert students work and practice and give them some help if they needed it. I can't help but take the time to mention another teacher I had in secondary school, both in relation to my artistic development and my development as a person. That would be John Gorman. My art history teacher. He was such an interesting man. One I, and I'd imagine anyone who has been graced with his presence will never forget. A sporter of too many languages and the grace of a Greek god. He is definitely to blame for my love, my true love and appreciation of both the art of today, and in particular the art of the past. As well asphilosophy and the more meaningful questions in life. You'd walk into his room for class and be overwhelmed by the unforgettable smell of a time gone by. Coffee and cigarettes. He smelled like the past. His timeworn, leather-bound watercolor notebook from the canal shop fronts of Venice. Piles of books, titled with ideas you'd never even thought to think of before.
It was around 3rd year that I got the Youtube Content creation bug and started creating my own content. Admittedly content around a card game but it was content. The process thought me a lot about what will and won't work in video, as well as what will and won't work outside of the video. The ideation phase. Execution. Delivery. I piloted this channel to a modest 1400 subscribers and total video view count of over half a million. Taking with me it's lessons into the future.
And that's it for this blog post. Thank you for reading! I will be continuing my story thus far in my next post. So until then. See you around.
Bill

item.title: Portfolio - Bill Stapleton
item.dc:creator: Bill
item.content:encoded:
My name is Bill Stapleton. I am a third year student of Creative Digital Media. My areas of interest are in Traditional as well as Digital Art and Design, Photography and Cinematography.
Throughout my three years of study I have completed modules relating to sound design, photography, film making and Brand Identity Design. Equipping myself both with knowledge of theory and skills with the tools to complete any task set to me.
Below I have included examples of my work enjoy and be sure to have a look at my blog if you would like to get a better idea of what kind of person and worker I am.
 
Music Video
One of the first video related assignments I worked on in college. Some nice shots in here that I am proud of.

item.title: Kai Man Wong, One of my biggest inspirations

item.title: World of Warcraft Interface Design My Obsession
item.dc:creator: Bill

item.title: Portfolio
item.dc:creator: Bill
item.content:encoded:
My name is Bill Stapleton. I am a third year student of Creative Digital Media. My areas of interest are in Traditional as well as Digital Art and Design, Photography and Cinematography. Throughout my three years of study I have completed modules relating to sound design, photography, film making and Brand Identity Design. Equipping myself both with knowledge of theory and skills with the tools to complete any task set to me. Below I have included examples of my work enjoy and be sure to have a look at my blog if you would like to get a better idea of what kind of person and worker I am.

Short Music Video

This short music video was one of the first projects I had ever worked on and was made in a day as part of a college assignment. The chance to work with the "emerging from the shadows" aesthetic was one I thoroughly enjoyed working with and one I definitely look forward to revisiting especially with my since evolved skills and knowledge.
[playlist type="video" ids="62,63,61,60,68,67,66,65,64"]
[playlist type="video" ids="80,79,78,77,76"]

The Theory of Turbulance

The Theory of Turbulance was a project I was introduced to by my Aunt Pat Culliton, on which I was a camera operator. On which I worked with people with far more experience than myself who I learned a lot from. Everything from on set etiquette as well as simple tips and tricks and techniques which I carry with me to this day. The project was intensive with all filming being done in a mere two days. It was however extremely rewarding.

Chalk Pastel On Canvas

Even in a digital age I find it is still important to practice and appriciate the traditional, physical art forms. Chalk pastel being one of my favourites particularly when working on canvas. Their ability to produce stunning saturated colours and beautiful textures wit such ease is unrivaled in my opinion. As well as their ability to scale and work seamlessly with other mediums, in this case Acrylic paint, even at a large scale. The three pieces on the right are among my favourites that I have done to day. Two of which I have sold, the third perched with pride over my workstation.
[playlist type="video" ids="109,110"]

Amira

Amira was created as part of a second year college project to increase awareness of the current Syrian refugee crysis. Designed to highlight that fact that the people everyone was hearing about in the news are far more than just a number or statistic on the news or in the newspaper. They were a person, a family with hopes and dreams. I worked on the project as part of a team of four. The other members being Cian Daly, Mairead McGuiness and Jordan Killion. With three of us focusing on animating we divided the project into three. Each of us taking a section. Mine being the ending. Starting from the fathers execution scene. Throughout the project I learned a lot about workflow and working with a near entirely digital medium. The tedious process was an excellent learning group for practicing digital painting and lead to my purchasing of a graphics monitor. A tool I grow to love more and more with each passing day as it enables me to paint digitally.

Stamped

Stamped is a short film I made alongside Cian Daly, Ola Dybul and Jordan Killion as part of a 3rd year Digital Film Making assignement on which I was Director of Photography and Cameraman. The project is currently in post production and I have to say I learned a lot from it. I took a lot away from working with the two main actors Cillein and Brid. They were excellent to work with a brought and new and enjoyable level of professionalism to the set. Since the film is still in post production I have included some notable snippets of footage for  you to enjoy until it is finished.
[playlist type="video" ids="73,72,70,69,75"]
